skos.definition: Serum sodium concentration above 145 mEq/L, always indicating a deficit of total body water relative to sodium, typically caused by inadequate water intake or excessive water loss.
skos.scopeNote: Primarily a disorder of water balance; hypernatremia implies hyperosmolality and cell shrinkage

content.title: Hypernatremia
content.summary: Hypernatremia (Na >145 mEq/L) always reflects a water deficit relative to sodium, occurring when water intake cannot match water losses. It primarily affects those unable to access water (elderly, debilitated, intubated patients) and requires careful free water replacement with gradual correction to prevent cerebral edema.
key_points: Always indicates hyperosmolality and free water deficit
Usually occurs in patients with impaired thirst or water access (elderly, intubated, debilitated)
Causes: inadequate water intake, excessive water loss (GI, renal, skin), rarely sodium excess
Diabetes insipidus (central or nephrogenic) causes renal water loss
Correct slowly: maximum 10-12 mEq/L per 24 hours to prevent cerebral edema
Acute (<48 hr): can correct faster; Chronic (>48 hr): correct slowly
content.statement: Hypernatremia represents a failure of water intake to match water losses. Unlike hyponatremia where water excess is common, hypernatremia indicates that intact thirst mechanisms are either not functioning or the patient cannot access water. Treatment focuses on restoring water balance while avoiding overcorrection.

explanation.intuition: Think of hypernatremia as 'too little water' rather than 'too much salt.' The serum sodium concentration is a ratio of sodium to water - when water is lost without proportional sodium loss, the concentration rises. This only happens when people can't drink enough water, either because they're unable to (intubated, demented) or their thirst is impaired (hypothalamic lesions, elderly).
explanation.key_insight: The brain adapts to chronic hypernatremia by accumulating organic osmolytes (taurine, glutamine, myo-inositol) to prevent shrinkage. If you correct sodium too quickly, these osmolytes draw water into brain cells causing cerebral edema - the opposite problem of osmotic demyelination in hyponatremia.
explanation.technical_details: Free water is regulated by ADH (vasopressin) and thirst. ADH is released in response to hyperosmolality or hypovolemia and acts on V2 receptors in the collecting duct to insert aquaporin-2 channels. In central DI, ADH is not produced; in nephrogenic DI, the kidney doesn't respond to ADH. The free water clearance formula (CH2O = V × (1 - Uosm/Posm)) quantifies renal water handling.

definitions_glossary.free_water_deficit: Amount of water needed to normalize sodium; calculated as 0.6 × body weight (kg) × ([Na]/140 - 1)
definitions_glossary.diabetes_insipidus: Disorder of water conservation; central (no ADH) or nephrogenic (resistance to ADH)
definitions_glossary.central_DI: Inadequate ADH production from hypothalamus/posterior pituitary; responds to desmopressin
definitions_glossary.nephrogenic_DI: Kidney resistance to ADH; caused by lithium, hypercalcemia, hypokalemia, genetic mutations
definitions_glossary.desmopressin: DDAVP - synthetic ADH analog; used to diagnose and treat central DI
definitions_glossary.polyuria: Urine output >3 L/day; seen in diabetes insipidus
definitions_glossary.polydipsia: Excessive thirst; protective response to hypernatremia
definitions_glossary.adipsia: Absence of thirst; causes severe hypernatremia due to lack of water-seeking behavior
definitions_glossary.osmotic_diuresis: Water loss driven by solute (glucose, urea, mannitol) causing polyuria
definitions_glossary.insensible_losses: Water lost through skin and respiration; increased with fever and tachypnea
definitions_glossary.free_water_clearance: Volume of plasma cleared of water per unit time; negative indicates water retention
definitions_glossary.serum_osmolality: Measure of dissolved particles; hypernatremia always causes hyperosmolality
definitions_glossary.aquaporin_2: Water channel inserted in collecting duct in response to ADH; absent in nephrogenic DI
definitions_glossary.urine_osmolality: Key diagnostic test; high in extrarenal losses, low in DI

pathophysiology.mechanism: Hypernatremia develops when water losses exceed water intake. Normal thirst response prevents hypernatremia unless thirst is impaired or water is inaccessible. The brain shrinks as water moves out of cells down the osmotic gradient.

renal: Central diabetes insipidus (pituitary surgery, trauma, tumors)
Nephrogenic DI (lithium, hypercalcemia, hypokalemia, tubulointerstitial disease)

inadequate_water_intake: Inability to access water (elderly, debilitated, intubated)
Dementia with neglect of fluid intake

clinical_presentation.neurological_consequences: Brain shrinkage can cause tearing of bridging veins → subdural/intracerebral hemorrhage

interpretation.urine_osm_greater_700: Appropriate concentration → extrarenal losses or inadequate intake
interpretation.urine_osm_300_700: Partial concentrating defect → partial DI or osmotic diuresis

water_deprivation_test.procedure: Withhold water until 3% weight loss or urine osm plateaus, then give desmopressin

interpretation.nephrogenic_DI: Urine osm does not respond to desmopressin

calculate_deficit.note: Use 0.5 for women and elderly due to lower total body water

correction_rate.chronic: Maximum 10-12 mEq/L per 24 hours (0.5 mEq/L per hour)
correction_rate.acute: Can correct faster if developed <48 hours
correction_rate.monitoring: Check sodium every 2-4 hours during active correction

fluid_choice.D5W: Free water IV; 1 L D5W = 1 L free water
fluid_choice.half_NS: 0.45% saline = 500 mL free water per liter
fluid_choice.NS: 0.9% saline; no free water but use if hypovolemic first

specific_treatment.central_DI: Desmopressin (intranasal, oral, or SC) + free water
specific_treatment.nephrogenic_DI: Thiazide diuretics (paradoxically reduce urine output), low-salt diet, NSAIDs

complications_of_treatment: Cerebral edema from overly rapid correction
Fluid overload if using isotonic saline

prognosis.mortality: Higher in elderly; acute hypernatremia >160 mEq/L has 40-60% mortality
prognosis.recovery: Good if identified and treated appropriately

learning_objectives: Explain why hypernatremia almost always reflects impaired water intake
Differentiate central from nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
Calculate free water deficit using appropriate formula
Describe safe correction rates for acute vs chronic hypernatremia
Interpret urine osmolality to identify the cause of hypernatremia
Outline treatment approaches for different etiologies
clinical_pearls: Hypernatremia in a patient with access to water = something is wrong with thirst mechanism
Lithium is the most common cause of acquired nephrogenic DI
High urine osm = kidneys are working normally; problem is inadequate water intake
Low urine osm despite hypernatremia = diabetes insipidus until proven otherwise
Don't use D5W for fluid resuscitation if hypovolemic - restore volume first with NS, then correct sodium with free water
Check sodium frequently - overcorrection causes cerebral edema

common_question_stems: Post-pituitary surgery patient with polyuria and Na 158
Patient on lithium with polyuria and dilute urine
Nursing home patient found with Na 162 and concentrated urine
exam_tips: Low urine osm + hypernatremia = DI; give desmopressin to differentiate central vs nephrogenic
Correct slowly in chronic hypernatremia to prevent cerebral edema

teaching_cases.scenario: 75-year-old woman with dementia from nursing home, Na 168, serum osm 348, urine osm 850, decreased skin turgor
teaching_cases.key_findings: High urine osm indicates kidneys are concentrating appropriately; problem is inadequate water intake
teaching_cases.diagnosis: Hypernatremia from inadequate oral intake (dehydration) in debilitated patient
teaching_cases.management: Calculate free water deficit, replace with D5W or oral water, correct slowly (<10-12 mEq/L per day)
